title: Trump Steers Clear of War Footing Toward Iran
text:
WASHINGTON—The White House is pushing to build an international coalition to exert pressure on Iran through the United Nations as its chief response to the attack on Saudi oil facilities, an approach consistent with President Trump’s aversion to military intervention, but also reflecting limits on his retaliatory options.

Within about 18 hours of 17 missile strikes on Saudi Arabia oil facilities on Saturday, the Trump administration pinned the blame squarely on Iran, which has denied carrying out the attacks. A day later, after an emergency meeting at the White House with his inner circle, Mr. Trump declared the U.S. “locked and loaded” and ready to respond.

But Mr. Trump’s assertive reaction was peppered with qualifiers—the U.S. intelligence still needed verification, he didn’t know what Riyadh knew, or how Saudi officials wanted to proceed. Since then, the emphasis has been on building a case with allies and others on Iran’s responsibility for the attacks and on signaling that sanctions on Iran will be stiffened.

On Wednesday, Saudi Arabia said it held Iran responsible for the attacks but didn’t directly accuse it of conducting them. U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called the attacks “an act of war,” though his remark was part of a speech about the need to pull together a coalition at the U.N., an institution Mr. Trump has repeatedly criticized and that his administration has rarely turned to for help and at times openly undermined.

Fears of a military conflict between the U.S. and Iran are high following an attack on a critical Saudi oil facility Saturday. WSJ’s Gerald F. Seib highlights three reasons the U.S. is less likely than it once was to defend Saudi Arabia if that happens. Photo: Associated Press

“We’re working to build out a coalition to develop a plan to deter them, this is what needs to happen,” Mr. Pompeo said aboard a flight to Saudi Arabia.

Also on Wednesday, Mr. Trump said he ordered Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to substantially raise sanctions on Iran. It was the first U.S. policy response to the attacks, but the administration didn’t immediately say what steps it would take, or what more, if anything, it was planning.

In another sign that the administration is far from a war footing, Mr. Trump made the comments while in California, where he flew earlier this week for a multiday, previously planned campaign fundraising trip.

“This president, he didn’t want to go to war with anybody, OK? That’s not his inclination,” said Sen. James Risch (R., Idaho), the Foreign Relations Committee chairman. “He will do everything he can to avoid a kinetic engagement with another country.”

There remains a possibility of a military response to the oil installation attacks, which caused the Saudi Arabian Oil Co., known as Aramco, to suspend production of 5.7 million barrels of oil a day, more than half of the country’s output and about 6% of the global supply.

Mr. Trump’s aversion to a more bellicose response—he publicly rebuked Sen. Lindsey Graham (R., S.C.) after he advocated for a military response against Iran—aligns with his “America First” approach to foreign policy and his distaste for military adventurism in the Middle East.

Mr. Graham suggested on Tuesday that the U.S. should respond by bombing an Iranian oil refinery. He has counseled Mr. Trump that the attacks on Aramco were meant to test his resolve. On Wednesday, he said that a military response should be strong enough to “restore deterrence.”

“It’s gotta be painful enough that they won’t do it again,” Mr. Graham said.

But Mr. Trump pushed back on Mr. Graham on Twitter and declined to weigh in on Mr. Pompeo’s remarks in Riyadh, saying a statement would be coming later. “We have many options that we’re considering,” Mr. Trump said to reporters before heading to a campaign fundraiser in San Diego. “There are many options.”

If a strike against Iranian interests happens, it is more likely to be measured and come from Saudi Arabia, with U.S. backing, than from the U.S. itself, according to interviews with administration officials and others who have been briefed on White House thinking.

The administration is also restricted in what action it can take. Mr. Trump is potentially hemmed in by a reluctant Congress, including many fellow Republicans. Some foreign allies are skeptical of U.S. intelligence that Mr. Pompeo used to finger Tehran on Saturday, people familiar with the matter said.

The strikes on Saudi Arabia’s oil infrastructure have led to a production shutdown on a scale the world hasn’t seen for decades. It could have long-lasting consequences for global markets and politics. Photo: Planet Labs Inc via AP

And there are also potential pitfalls for Mr. Trump’s own re-election bid, which may rise or fall on the strength of the U.S. economy. Although the U.S. is insulated from oil-supply shocks because it is now largely energy self-sufficient, the global economy remains a potential drag on U.S. growth, and Saturday’s attacks prompted a major jump in oil prices. Any escalation in military conflict could drive prices higher for longer.

The administration’s preferred option, according to multiple officials, remains a coordinated international response through the U.N., which gathers next week for its General Assembly in New York, where Mr. Trump and Mr. Pompeo are expected to make an appearance.

The turn to the U.N. was an unlikely wrinkle for the Trump administration, which has extensively criticized the institution. The U.S. withdrew from the Human Rights Commission last year, attacking it as a “hypocritical and self-serving organization that makes a mockery of human rights,” and relegated the post of U.S. ambassador to the U.N. to a level below the president’s cabinet.

As a presidential candidate, Mr. Trump spoke of the “utter weakness and incompetence of the United Nations” in a speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee. “The United Nations is not a friend of democracy, it’s not a friend to freedom, it’s not a friend even to the United States of America,” he charged.

But on Wednesday, Mr. Trump cited the “tremendous potential” of the U.N.: “I’ve always felt the United Nations is very important.”

The Trump administration has, on occasion, utilized the U.N. In March 2018, the White House led the effort to impose a package of sanctions aimed at curtailing revenues for North Korea’s ballistic-missile and nuclear programs.

Earlier this week, during a U.N. Security Council session to address the situation in Yemen, U.S. Ambassador Kelly Craft said Iran was responsible for the attack on two Saudi oil plants, and not the Iran-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen that claimed credit.

Trump administration officials said there were 17 missiles used in the attack, which contradicted the Houthi claim that they launched 10 drones from Yemen. A separate oil facility was struck at least twice by precision-guided munitions, an administration official said.

“You can demonstrate that the Houthi claim does not stand up to scrutiny,” the official said.

But British U.N. Ambassador Karen Pierce said responsibility hadn’t been determined. Japan and France have also signaled to the U.S. that they aren’t convinced Iran was behind the attack.

A British embassy spokeswoman in Washington said it was too early to say if, and how, the U.K. could join a diplomatic coalition to respond to the attack on Saudi Arabia’s oil infrastructure.

“We are still working to establish the facts of what happened, and I won’t pre-empt next steps,” the spokeswoman said. “We will work with international partners to agree on the most effective response.”

—Vivian Salama contributed to this article.

Write to Michael C. Bender at Mike.Bender@wsj.com, Jessica Donati at jessica.donati@wsj.com and Lindsay Wise at lindsay.wise@wsj.com
